awd_titl_txt: CAREER: From Performance-Based Engineering to Resilience and Sustainability: Design and Assessment Principles for the Next Generation of Buildings
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award is to create a unified design and assessment methodology that accounts for the various ways that cost, resilience to hazards, resource consumption, and environmental and social impacts are interconnected throughout a building's service life.  A major challenge related to developing the next generation of buildings in the United States is increasing their resilience to natural hazards, while, at the same time, incorporating sustainable practices into their construction, maintenance, and operation over their lifespan. Current approaches to quantifying building performance are largely based on individual attributes such as energy efficiency, resilience to hazards, or cost. However, these attributes are often in conflict with each other, making definitive design solutions elusive. Through a unified design and assessment methodology, this holistic treatment of a building's life cycle performance will provide insights into the possible benefits, interdependencies, and tradeoffs associated with specific resilience and sustainability strategies. The research findings will be integrated into the educational and public outreach components of the project including (a) new curricula that prepares future practitioners, academic faculty, and decision-makers to address complex building design, assessment, and management problems, (b) sustained engagement in initiatives to recruit and retain underrepresented minorities and women in structural/earthquake engineering, and (c) an interactive exhibit that will be showcased at various community-based institutions in the Los Angeles area, to raise public awareness of the opportunities and challenges faced when implementing strategies to enhance the resilience and sustainability of buildings.
	
A discrete-event simulation model will be used to quantify, in a probabilistic manner, the effect of earthquake-related disruption on a building's service life functionality. The model will account for the interaction among seismic resilience and economic, environmental, and social impacts. Life cycle performance optimization algorithms will be formulated to consider multiple stakeholder preferences and objectives. Another aspect of the research will be directed towards creating a multi-criteria decision-making framework that supports the design and service life management of seismic building systems. The scientific methods and tools to be developed as part of the research program will be evaluated and validated by using them to conduct case studies in the design and life cycle assessment for a set of real buildings. The research program will benefit the broader society by enabling developers to provide more compelling reasons to owners in both the private and public sectors to request enhanced building systems with resilient and sustainable features that exceed the minimum performance level found in most U.S. design codes. The value derived from improved service-life functionality and reduced life cycle environmental and economic costs will have the potential to offer building owners dramatically greater returns on their investment.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
By minimizing the cumulative loss of functionality following a natural hazard event, buildings contribute to community resilience. At the same time, buildings that minimize their environmental footprint over the life cycle is also desired. This CAREER project developed research, education, and public outreach programs to advance life cycle design of resilience and sustainable buildings

A major goal of this project was to understand and quantify the performance implications of buildings subjected to multiple seismic events over their lifetime. To this end, one of the early studies developed a statistical approach estimating the aftershock collapse vulnerability of buildings using predictor variables related to the mainshock shaking intensity, structural response measures and indicators of physical damage. A key finding was that features based on observations of overall mainshock damage provided better predictions of aftershock performance than those based on structural responses from the preceding event. In a separate study that used the Markov process to quantify aftershock collapse risk, we found that considering the contribution of aftershocks to the total seismic risk in the pre-mainshock environment could result in an increase of up to three times in the likelihood of collapse during an assumed lifetime of 50 years. We also developed a methodology to quantify life cycle seismic loss considering multiple events. Through a case study application, we found that the contribution of aftershocks to the total earthquake-induced losses was significant with the losses under mainshock-aftershock seismic sequences being up to 30% larger than the losses under the mainshock-only scenario. We then extended the loss assessment methodology to portfolios of buildings and determined that the aftershock losses can be as much as 30% of the mainshock losses during a one-week period following the event.

A second focus of this project was to establish mathematical models to evaluate the life cycle performance of protective seismic building systems while considering the tradeoff between resilience and sustainability. The controlled rocking steel braced frame (CRBF) system was considered for this purpose. Recognizing their strong implications to life cycle performance, we first developed a reliability-based methodology to quantify the relationship between the response of the CRSBF force-controlled components (frame beams, columns, and braces) and system level performance (collapse and post-earthquake structural safety). We found that the failure of force-controlled components had a much greater effect on post-earthquake safety compared to collapse performance. The primary study in this thread of research developed a performance-based methodology to determine the optimal CRSBF design parameters that will minimize the combined upfront cost (of the CRSBF only) and earthquake-induced economic losses and environmental impacts (CO2 emissions). We found that, compared to economic losses, life cycle CO2 emissions was more sensitive to the CRSBF design parameters.

The third research thread investigated the feasibility of using artificial intelligence and automation to enhance performance-based seismic design and assessment. As part of this endeavor, we developed an end-to-end computational platform that automates seismic design, nonlinear structural model construction, and response simulation of steel moment resisting frames (AutoSDA). Using the AutoSDA platform, we generated a database of 621 special steel moment-resisting frames designed in accordance with modern codes and standards and their corresponding nonlinear structural models and seismic responses. These responses were used to examine a spectrum of simplified methods for estimating building seismic drift demands is conceptualized. On one extreme are mechanics-based approaches that are derived solely from fundamental engineering principles. On the other end are purely data-driven models that are developed using parametric data sets generated from nonlinear response history analyses. Between these two extremes, there are models that combine elements of basic engineering principles and statistical learning (hybrid models). We found that the hybrid models had the most accurate predictive performance while the mechanics-based models required the most effort to implement.

The main educational and public outreach component of the project engaged undergraduate students in the development of a digital exhibit on “Resilience and Sustainability Strategies for the Next Generation of Buildings”. The exhibit includes background information on resilience and sustainability, a timeline of earthquakes in California and resulting code changes and policy, an introduction to the CRSBF as a high-performance seismic system and an interactive interface that allows users to define specific CRSBF design parameters and observe the change in life cycle cost and environmental impact.

By allowing stakeholders and designers to explore look-ahead scenarios, the models and tools developed as part of this project will provide insights into the possible benefits, interdependencies and tradeoffs associated with specific resilience and sustainability strategies. To facilitate technology transfer to other researchers and disaster risk managers, the AutoSDA tool has been published on GitHub and the database of steel moment frames has been uploaded to the DesignSafe platform. Four PhD students and numerous undergraduate students worked on the project. To date, sixteen journal manuscripts have been published along with several papers in conference proceedings.

 


Last Modified: 04/28/2022
Modified by: Henry V Burton
